bboxes.raw_text:
WASHINCTON-The report of
a ten man scientific panel, who
studied the effects of smoking for
fourteen months, was made final
earlier this week.


The panel concluded smoking
cigarettes is hazardous and is
a major cause of lung cancer and
other respiratory diseases.


Surgeon General Luther Terry.
head of the US. Public Health
Service, accepted the report and
said remedial action is needed.
He said if he were a doctor he
would warn his patients against
smoking.


The report also linked smok-
ing pipes with the development
of cancer of the lip.

Another postponement of the
trial of Ruby Lee Bates, AZ,
CHI arged with murder, was
granted. The new date is Feb.
8. Judge Laurens L. Henderson
permitted the latest delay be-
cause of the illness of vi.
Hash. defense lawyer.


The previous delay was be-
cause Of the disqualification of
the defendant for a gall bladder
operation. She is accused of the
shooting-slaying Aug. 10 of Josh
Myles, As, of 17l0 E. Lincoln,
in her apartment at OLA w.
Grant.

AVONDALE-A Phoenix woman
survived a car plunge into the
Roosevelt District Canal but later
drowned. sheriff 8 deputies said.


She was identified as Marie
Kemp. 38, 1898 E. Adams.


Deputies reported she was with
Allen Hilton, Sc, of 2410 w.
Adams, when the car went into
the canal. Both climbed onto the
submerged car 8 hood.


Hilton told deputies when he
turned she was gone. Hilton was
taken to county hospital for ex-
animation.


Deputies said. the woman may
have been swept from the car
by the strong current. Her body
was found a mile from the car.

]. D. Dobbs, Jr., president of the
firm which operates Dobbs
Houses and Toddle Houses. He
said some places in Atlanta, Ten
nessee and Texas had been In
tegrated.


Dick Gregory. famous Negro
comedian is a stakeholder in the
firm. His wife was recently ar
rested during a sitin at a Dobbs
restaurant in Atlanta.

NEW YORK-New York City
schools will be boycotted starting
Feb. 8 by civil rights groups
who are dissatisfied with the
Board of Education 8 integration
program.


Frederick Jones, education
chairman of the state 8 NAACP
branches, said the boycott would
Be operated in cooperation with
the Citywide Committee for
School Integration which includes
the NAACP, CORE and two large
parents groups.

PHILADELPHIA = Richardson
Dilworth, former mayor of Phil
adelphia, who was hailed for his
liberal policies, told Chamber
of Commerce seminar last week
that, "The time has come for the
Negro to stop feeling so damned
sorry for himself"


He continued, "We cannot sup
port 20 per cent of the Negroes
in the North on relief and hope
to survive"


Dilworth, known as an out
spoken man, regards Negro lead
ers who insist because they be-
long to a minority group that they
can't get anywhere.


He told his audience that Ne
groes should look at the Irish and
Italians who were once minori-
ties. One of them became presi-
dent.


Dilworth continued saying the
trouble caused by the blacldace
makeup in the mummers parade
set the Negro community back
ten years.

FORMER PHILLY


MAYOR URGES NEGRO
TO STOP SELF PITY

NAACP executive secretary
Roy wilkins reported at the As
ISOLATION s annual meeting total
of 515,396 members on closing
date Dec. "a. This figure repre-
sents an additional III 1888 mem
bers over 1862, an increase of
% per cent.


Youth membership reached
55,S67, a so per cent increase
over the 1862 total.


A record number of new units
were chartered during the year,
100 branches, youth councils,
college chapters and young adult
councils. The newly-chartered
units brought the total to LIS,
the highest in the history Of the
organization. There are active
units in the District of Columbia
and in every state of the Union
except Alabama where the As
ISOLATION has been banned by
state court injunction since 1856.


Chicago with a total of 81 500
was the largest single branch in
the Association. However, the IL
branches in the five boroughs of
New York City enrolled a total of
34,O11.


Second largest single branch in
the country was Detroit with
28,443. followed by Philadelphia.
"a, 48l. Other branches with
10000 or more members inclu-
ded Cleveland, 1904; Balti-
more, 1858; Washington, H.
EOS: Pittsburgh. l0.457 and
Brooklyn, 10000.


In every area Of its activity
the NAACP saw outstanding sue
cess in 1868. The Youth and
College Division, the largest
youth civil rights group in the
nation, massed its members for
sit-ins. stand-ins, drive-ins,
wade-ins, mass demonstrations,
protest marches, picket lines and
selective buying campaigns in
virtually every section of the
country.

LOS ANG ELES-Ground break
ing ceremonies for the first all
Negro owned and organized bank
west of Kansas City were held
last week.


DR.. Edward H. Ballard, board
chairman, led ceremonies. He
was assisted by C. E. Trimmer,
manager of Southern California
Gas Co., and City Councilman
Tome Bradley, who Is one of the
banks organizers.


The bank is capitalized at
ST. ,05O.OOO and deposits of SIS
million have been assured for the
opening date in June.


1t will be located at 2651 So.
Western Ave. and will provide all
banking facilities.


The bank was organized by
DR.. Ballard, DR.. Perry w. Beal,
Milton A. Clarke, Onie B. Gran
Vile, Mrs. Bernice M. Malbrue,
Lorenzo V. Spence and Coun-
Gilman Bradley.


DR.. Ballard stressed the bank
will have an integrated staff of
employees.

NEGRO BANK
TO OPEN IN
LOS ANGELES

NEW YORK = Rep. Adam Clay
ton Powell O-N.Y.) did not ap-
pear before Supreme Court JUS
tice Arthur MarkeMch Jan. e
as originally ordered because
the date had been cancelled.


Opposing counsel in the de-
famation suit filed against him
by Mrs. Esther Matilda James
agreed before Justice Charles
D. Breitel last week that every
thing should be delayed until
the Appellate Court rules on the
merits Of the suit.


Mrs. James was awarded
SILL 500 in damages by a jury
after she accused the Harlem
Congressman of libel by calling
her a "bag woman who col
lected graft for New York po-
lice. The remarks were made on
a TV program.


Mrs. James said she will fight
the case until Powell pays.

MEMPHIS-Dobbs Houses, Inc,
chain of snack rooms and res


taurants, will have some desc
gregated facilities in the South.


The announcement was made by
